On Pressure
by Bill Riesen
The Student Council voted
unanimously to voice its support for "Personal and Interpersonal Excellence in a
Changing World," a series of
informal workshops on dealing
with the tensions and pressures
students feel in the Hopkins'
academic environment.
The program, sponsored
jointly by the Office of the
Chaplain, the Residential Life
Office, and the Baltimore office
of the National Conference of
Christians and Jews, aims at
addressing "attitudes and
values which determine social,
academic and career success."
It will include panel discussions
held October 8 and 15 on living
in a pluralistic community and
academic integrity.
Citing the "diverse, competitive and intense" academic
climate at Hopkins, the council resolution encourages all
students to take part in the
workshops and specifies that a
council member will participate
in each panel discussion.
Council members quickly
agreed to back the resolution;
it was passed with no debate
and little discussion. "There's
hardly any question" but that
the program merits attention,
said Vice President Mary Hiatt.
"It's asking for support on
something that's obviously important to all of us."
"I think it's great that issues
like this are being addressed,"
added Senior Class President
Paul Donio. "The council
should give its wholehearted
support."

William Henry Welch Lecture
Series, "The Culture of
Medicine" will begin its second
year of presentations at
Homewood with a lecture by
Thomas Pollard, the Bayard
Halsted Professor of Cell
Biology and Anatomy at the
School of Medicine. Pollard's
topic will be "Contractile Proteins and Cell Motility."

neuroscience,
genetics,
psychiatry and general questions of policy-making in health
genetics. In addition to
Pollard's, there will be three
further lectures this academic
year.

McKusick, professor of
Medicine and Medical Genetics,
will present an overview of his
field on February 4. Donald
Henderson, Dean of the School
of Hygiene and Public Health,
will survey the challenge and
problems facing those in the
medical professions today, and
on March 4, Dr. Richard Ross,
Dean of the Medical Faculty,
will discuss new orientations in
teaching and research at the
Medical School.
The lectures are free, and are
given in the Garrett Room of
the Milton S. Eisenhower
Library, usually commencing at
4:30 pm.

The Hopkins News-Letter Hopkins Students:
Express Yourself
A Mixed Report
Or Be Forgotten
Rarely has there been a furor at
Homewood as great as last year's hubbub over the TEP newsletter incident.
The whole affair has just now
culminated in a huge report on women
at Hopkins, some of which is quite sensible, and some of which is quite silly.
For freshmen, or those who were on
Mars last year, the whole thing started
when a member of the Feminist Alliance
accidentally received a copy of an
obscene Tau Epsilon Phi fraternity
newsletter in her Gilman Hall mailbox.
The feminist group subsequently
publicized the newsletter, and the administration slapped some penalties on
TEP.
But the deans also followed up on the
whole affair, appointing Ruth Leys to a
newly-created job as Special Assistant to
the Deans on Women's Issues, and then
appointing the committee which just
reported.
There is a danger the report will be
viewed as an ending. The committee has
done its job, some will say, so the issue
is closed. Wrong. The issue is just now
coming into its most critical moment.
The administration needs to act—
quickly—on the report's worthwhile
recommendations.
Let's first say the obvious: parts of the
report are not only not worthwhile, they
are ridiculous. In particular, the report
advocates the hiring of dozens of additional personnel. At a small university,
that simply isn't possible; the money just
isn't there.
The report says blithely, for example,
that four new tenured faculty positions
ought to be created specifically for
women. Leaving aside for the moment

whether or not that's a good idea, it's utterly unreasonable.
Perhaps the committtee members
thought that by asking for a mile they
could bargain down to an inch. It's more
likely people will disregard the report as
unrealistic rantings.
That would be unfortunate, for there
is much in the report that makes a lot of
sense. In particular, we like the emphasis
placed on increasing the number of
women on the faculty. Dean of the
School of Arts and Sciences George
Fisher has said he and the other deans
will appoint a committee to study the
report's recommendations in that area.
But why hasn't such a committee already
started working? Admittedly not much
can be done in the summer, but the
academic year is a month old. Fisher promises the committee in a few days. We'll
keep an eye on him, but so should
students.
The report's call for a day care center
also deserves attention. Fisher says there
will be "conversations" about the
center's establishment. He is indisputably honest, but that sounds like
foot dragging. Recommendations on
publicizing the problems of sexual
harassment and improving educational
opportunities for employees are also
reasonable.
So far, the administration has done
virtually nothing to implement anything
contained in the report. We'll grant that
it's early in the year, but visible progress
needs to be made soon. At the same
time, the committee should be chastised
for having written a report which at
times is completely unrealistic. At this
point, nobody has much to be proud of.

Relations between Hopkins and the
surrounding community have never been
exactly wonderful. After this summer's

Tears For Fears: It's a Civic Center World
by Sue Trowbridge
I seldom venture into arenas.
But the prospect of Tears for
Fears playing a mere thirty-five
blocks from my home was hard
to resist. After all, I had liked
them back in the days when
they probably couldn't have
filled Shriver Hall, much less
the Civic Center; I really
wanted to go see them, and I
wasn't going to let ten thousand
15-year-olds with paisley jeans
and perfectly moussed hair deter
me.
On the bus to the concert, I
suddenly realized that I had
forgotten to bring my good old
Flents earplugs. This was a major mistake. Many hours after
the show, I'm still a bit deaf in
my left ear, the one that was
facing the wall of speakers on
the stage.
Arriving at the Civic Center,
I surveyed the crowd. Although
it was predominantly young
and female, there were also
biker types with tatoos, lots of
college-aged people, even someone wearing a jacket with
the logo of D.C. hardcore band
Minor Threat on the back.
Most of them were still
roaming the corridors when the
opening band, The Adventures,
came on at 7:35 p.m. In the
grand tradition of warmup

Tears For Fears: The Guys—The Haircuts

acts, they were overwhelmingly mediocre, pumping out
unoriginal pop-rock tunes for a
mercifully short half hour. Of
course, they also had the
obligatory female backup
vocalist in tight pants banging
on a tamborine.
It took about 45 minutes for
Tears For Fears to take the
stage. As I waited, I decided
that being at a concert with lots
of young teens had its
advantages—there was hardly
any smoke in the air, cigarette
or otherwise.
' But, when the lights went

down, I realized that life is indeed full of little tradeoffs.
Seated right behind me were
half a dozen girls who were apparently finalists in the
Pillsbury Scream-Off.
Tears For Fears kicked their
set with a lukewarm version of
"Mothers Talk," but things
picked up when they launched
into their current single," Head
Over Heels," which has got to
be the most gorgeous song to
hit the pop charts in ages.
Singer Roland Orzabal's voice
sounded wonderful here, soaring easily into a falsetto. Listen-

ing to Orzabal sing may have
been a pure pleasure, but unfortunately, his between-song
patter was like something out
of a bad Las Vegas revue—
"God bless you and your
children, and your children's
children," etc.
Of course, not all of Tears
For Fears' songs are as good as
"Head Over Heels" or "Pale
Shelter," their third number.
There were a couple of slow
and boring ones in the middle.
During the plodding "Start
of the Breakdown," I amused
myself by watching the drama
of a girl near the stage who
threw a large hoop earring at
Curt Smith, Tears For Fears
other lead singer. She was promptly accosted by a brawny
security guard who began to
lead her away, but she must
have pleat-bargained, since she
managed to stay put.
Among the show's highlights
was "The Working Hour,"
another beauty from Songs
From The Chair, their current
LP. Their saxophonist was put
to particularly good use here,
contributing an elegant solo.
They also did an excellent
version of their big hit
"Shout," which finished off
with all seven members of the
band at the front of the stage,
chanting the mindless but cat-

chy lyrics to the accompaniment of a drum machine.
All in all, each of the eight
songs on Songs From The Big
Chair were played (although
the version of "Listen" was
purely an instrumental interlude before the curtain went
up). But they also did many of
their early tracks from The
Hurting, which rivals Joy Division for stark depressing lyrics.
I never thought I'd see thousand of jubilant, Bic-flicking
teens swaying along to rhymes
like Mad World's "I find it
kind of funny, I find it kind of
sad/The dreams in which I'm
dying are the best I ever had."
Other pluses—the lighting
was incredible, and the drummer provided a mighty beat.
The sound, in fact, was better
than I can ever remember hearing at any arena show, instead
of the muddy mess that often
results in such cavernous
venues.
But then again, my last arena
show was two and a half years
ago. If the Civic Center
featured more concerts by pop
bands as good as Tears For
Fears, instead of just being a
heavy metal showcase for
AC/DC, Dio, and the like,
Baltimore's music scene would
improve considerably.

9, 1985, marked the completion

$600,000 grant made by the

among the oldest academic
buildings on the Homewood
campus.

centered on rebuilding the rear
wing of Maryland that was

Machinery Hall was itself a
two-story addition that provided lab space for professors who
required a large open area.

all types had taken place in
Machinery Hall and slowly
these experiments also took
their toll on the structure.
Everything from a large mass
of 18-inch thick concrete radio
frequency shielding, to a wind
tunnel, to large pieces of
machinery, and even a ceiling
crane, had found itself in the
hall. With the 1977 deicision to
re-establish the School of
Engineering at Hopkins came
the commitment to re-equip
this new school. This commitment came to an early fruition
in the decision to renovate
Maryland Machinery Hall.

engineering at Hopkins to its
earlier level of excellence, was
accompanied by the need to re-

establish two new departments,
Civil
Engineering
and
Mechanical Engineering. The
creation of these two departments, it was recognized, would
create a great need for additional lab and classroom space.
Fortunately for the Whiting
School, just at the time that it
was growing, the University
received a gift to build Olin
Hall for the Department of
Earth and Planetary Sciences.
With this department no longer
in Latrobe Hall, the Whiting
School had substantially more
space. The long term use of
Latrobe Hall, however, required a major renovation of
the entire structure. The need
for even more space for
engineering was becoming apparent. Thus, when Dean V.
David VandeLinde developed
the idea that the earth depression behind Latrobe Hall be
filled in with an underground
lab wing the suggestion was
taken seriously.

Bolstered by an improved
scoring attack, the Hopkins
soccer team coasted to two consecutive victories this past
week. The victories lifted the
team's record to 5-1 and extended their winning streak to
five games.
Last Saturday, the Blue Jays
dumped Coppin State 3-0. The
squad dominated the game, and
outshot the Knights 21-10.
Chris Niyogi, Craig Weinstein
and Steve Gallo accounted for
the game's only scoring tallies.
Junior goalkeeper Ray Guirieo
made one save in posting his
third shutout of the season, and
lowering his goals against
average to .040.
On Wednesday, Hopkins
thrashed York 6-0. Again, the
Jays completely controlled the
game's play and outshot their
opponent 15-0. Two goals from

Charlie Digby and single tallies
from Dave Gallo, Andy
Nichols, Grenville Jones, and
Craig Weinstein accounted for
the scoring in this lopsided affair. Goalies Eric Shaw and
Giuriceo combined to make
five saves in the team's fourth
shutout of the year. Head
Coach William Tierney was
very pleased with the team's
performance and especially the
play of senior tri-captain Dan
Olszewki.
"Dan played by far his best
game of the year," the coach
remarked. "He's been a steady
player all season but he really
came to life against York. He
accounted for an assist, but the
important things that he does
for us don't show up in the
scoring column."
If the defense continues to
stymie opponents and the scoring threats connect, one can only be led to believe that the

Hooters are playoff-bound.
The squad has an excellent
balance of youth and experience, and the upcoming
games should be a good
measuring stick of just how
strong the Jays really are.
Coach Tierney wants to take
one game at a time rather than
look ahead.
"We're in a good positon
now," Tierney remarked. "The
attitude and depth of talent on
this team are both excellent.

confidence and place ourselves
in a better positon to realize our
goals. Taking one game at a
time, we should be successful at
the season's end." Hopkins'
road swing rounds out with
meetings at Ursinus tomorrow
and Division II power
U.M.B.C. Wednesday. They
return home Friday to face
Dickinson.

The Hopkins News-Letter Hopkins Students:
Express Yourself
A Mixed Report
Or Be Forgotten
Rarely has there been a furor at
Homewood as great as last year's hubbub over the TEP newsletter incident.
The whole affair has just now
culminated in a huge report on women
at Hopkins, some of which is quite sensible, and some of which is quite silly.
For freshmen, or those who were on
Mars last year, the whole thing started
when a member of the Feminist Alliance
accidentally received a copy of an
obscene Tau Epsilon Phi fraternity
newsletter in her Gilman Hall mailbox.
The feminist group subsequently
publicized the newsletter, and the administration slapped some penalties on
TEP.
But the deans also followed up on the
whole affair, appointing Ruth Leys to a
newly-created job as Special Assistant to
the Deans on Women's Issues, and then
appointing the committee which just
reported.
There is a danger the report will be
viewed as an ending. The committee has
done its job, some will say, so the issue
is closed. Wrong. The issue is just now
coming into its most critical moment.
The administration needs to act—
quickly—on the report's worthwhile
recommendations.
Let's first say the obvious: parts of the
report are not only not worthwhile, they
are ridiculous. In particular, the report
advocates the hiring of dozens of additional personnel. At a small university,
that simply isn't possible; the money just
isn't there.
The report says blithely, for example,
that four new tenured faculty positions
ought to be created specifically for
women. Leaving aside for the moment

whether or not that's a good idea, it's utterly unreasonable.
Perhaps the committtee members
thought that by asking for a mile they
could bargain down to an inch. It's more
likely people will disregard the report as
unrealistic rantings.
That would be unfortunate, for there
is much in the report that makes a lot of
sense. In particular, we like the emphasis
placed on increasing the number of
women on the faculty. Dean of the
School of Arts and Sciences George
Fisher has said he and the other deans
will appoint a committee to study the
report's recommendations in that area.
But why hasn't such a committee already
started working? Admittedly not much
can be done in the summer, but the
academic year is a month old. Fisher promises the committee in a few days. We'll
keep an eye on him, but so should
students.
The report's call for a day care center
also deserves attention. Fisher says there
will be "conversations" about the
center's establishment. He is indisputably honest, but that sounds like
foot dragging. Recommendations on
publicizing the problems of sexual
harassment and improving educational
opportunities for employees are also
reasonable.
So far, the administration has done
virtually nothing to implement anything
contained in the report. We'll grant that
it's early in the year, but visible progress
needs to be made soon. At the same
time, the committee should be chastised
for having written a report which at
times is completely unrealistic. At this
point, nobody has much to be proud of.

A Day in the Park
Relations between Hopkins and the
surrounding community have never been
exactly wonderful. After this summer's
brouhaha over Wyman Park, they may
be worse than ever.
In short, the university asked permission to develop five acres of the park.
Additional space is needed for research,
so the school planned to build two new
office complexes. The mayor had apparently suggested the idea, but backed
away due to community uproar.
The community claimed the university didn't really need the land, and argued
the park is a valuable asset to the area.
The matter is to be resolved this
month.
Whatever the outcome, it seems clear
the university committed a public relations blunder.
Presumably the timing of the move—
smack in the middle of the summer—
was thought to be beneficial. Students
and faculty, the two university-connected
groups most likely to sympathize with
the community, would be out of touch
with the school; many community
members would be on vacation. In

retrospect, though, the timing could not
have been worse. It looked as if the
university was trying to sneak one by
everybody.
Then, in attempting to make matters
better, University President Steven
Muller may have made them worse. In
a letter to The Sun (which is reprinted
on the page opposite), he included a
preachy reference to the dictionary that
could only have served to anger more
people.
The matter is a serious one because
Hopkins has often had trouble with the
rest of Baltimore in the past. That isn't
too surprising—Hopkins is clearly a bastion of upper-class privilege in a profoundly middle class area, and students
no doubt often come off as arrogant
smart alecks. In that sense, no matter
what the university does, some members
of the community won't like it.
Still, there was no reason for Hopkins
to antagonize so many people with its
move to take over the park. Handled
correctly, the expansion could have come
off smoothly.

Tears For Fears: It's a Civic Center World
by Sue Trowbridge
I seldom venture into arenas.
But the prospect of Tears for
Fears playing a mere thirty-five
blocks from my home was hard
to resist. After all, I had liked
them back in the days when
they probably couldn't have
filled Shriver Hall, much less
the Civic Center; I really
wanted to go see them, and I
wasn't going to let ten thousand
15-year-olds with paisley jeans
and perfectly moussed hair deter
me.
On the bus to the concert, I
suddenly realized that I had
forgotten to bring my good old
Flents earplugs. This was a major mistake. Many hours after
the show, I'm still a bit deaf in
my left ear, the one that was
facing the wall of speakers on
the stage.
Arriving at the Civic Center,
I surveyed the crowd. Although
it was predominantly young
and female, there were also
biker types with tatoos, lots of
college-aged people, even someone wearing a jacket with
the logo of D.C. hardcore band
Minor Threat on the back.
Most of them were still
roaming the corridors when the
opening band, The Adventures,
came on at 7:35 p.m. In the
grand tradition of warmup

Tears For Fears: The Guys—The Haircuts

acts, they were overwhelmingly mediocre, pumping out
unoriginal pop-rock tunes for a
mercifully short half hour. Of
course, they also had the
obligatory female backup
vocalist in tight pants banging
on a tamborine.
It took about 45 minutes for
Tears For Fears to take the
stage. As I waited, I decided
that being at a concert with lots
of young teens had its
advantages—there was hardly
any smoke in the air, cigarette
or otherwise.
' But, when the lights went

down, I realized that life is indeed full of little tradeoffs.
Seated right behind me were
half a dozen girls who were apparently finalists in the
Pillsbury Scream-Off.
Tears For Fears kicked their
set with a lukewarm version of
"Mothers Talk," but things
picked up when they launched
into their current single," Head
Over Heels," which has got to
be the most gorgeous song to
hit the pop charts in ages.
Singer Roland Orzabal's voice
sounded wonderful here, soaring easily into a falsetto. Listen-

ing to Orzabal sing may have
been a pure pleasure, but unfortunately, his between-song
patter was like something out
of a bad Las Vegas revue—
"God bless you and your
children, and your children's
children," etc.
Of course, not all of Tears
For Fears' songs are as good as
"Head Over Heels" or "Pale
Shelter," their third number.
There were a couple of slow
and boring ones in the middle.
During the plodding "Start
of the Breakdown," I amused
myself by watching the drama
of a girl near the stage who
threw a large hoop earring at
Curt Smith, Tears For Fears
other lead singer. She was promptly accosted by a brawny
security guard who began to
lead her away, but she must
have pleat-bargained, since she
managed to stay put.
Among the show's highlights
was "The Working Hour,"
another beauty from Songs
From The Chair, their current
LP. Their saxophonist was put
to particularly good use here,
contributing an elegant solo.
They also did an excellent
version of their big hit
"Shout," which finished off
with all seven members of the
band at the front of the stage,
chanting the mindless but cat-

chy lyrics to the accompaniment of a drum machine.
All in all, each of the eight
songs on Songs From The Big
Chair were played (although
the version of "Listen" was
purely an instrumental interlude before the curtain went
up). But they also did many of
their early tracks from The
Hurting, which rivals Joy Division for stark depressing lyrics.
I never thought I'd see thousand of jubilant, Bic-flicking
teens swaying along to rhymes
like Mad World's "I find it
kind of funny, I find it kind of
sad/The dreams in which I'm
dying are the best I ever had."
Other pluses—the lighting
was incredible, and the drummer provided a mighty beat.
The sound, in fact, was better
than I can ever remember hearing at any arena show, instead
of the muddy mess that often
results in such cavernous
venues.
But then again, my last arena
show was two and a half years
ago. If the Civic Center
featured more concerts by pop
bands as good as Tears For
Fears, instead of just being a
heavy metal showcase for
AC/DC, Dio, and the like,
Baltimore's music scene would
improve considerably.

Hooters Roll Record To 5-1

Bolstered by an improved
scoring attack, the Hopkins
soccer team coasted to two consecutive victories this past
week. The victories lifted the
team's record to 5-1 and extended their winning streak to
five games.
Last Saturday, the Blue Jays
dumped Coppin State 3-0. The
squad dominated the game, and
outshot the Knights 21-10.
Chris Niyogi, Craig Weinstein
and Steve Gallo accounted for
the game's only scoring tallies.
Junior goalkeeper Ray Guirieo
made one save in posting his
third shutout of the season, and
lowering his goals against
average to .040.
On Wednesday, Hopkins
thrashed York 6-0. Again, the
Jays completely controlled the
game's play and outshot their
opponent 15-0. Two goals from

Charlie Digby and single tallies
from Dave Gallo, Andy
Nichols, Grenville Jones, and
Craig Weinstein accounted for
the scoring in this lopsided affair. Goalies Eric Shaw and
Giuriceo combined to make
five saves in the team's fourth
shutout of the year. Head
Coach William Tierney was
very pleased with the team's
performance and especially the
play of senior tri-captain Dan
Olszewki.
"Dan played by far his best
game of the year," the coach
remarked. "He's been a steady
player all season but he really
came to life against York. He
accounted for an assist, but the
important things that he does
for us don't show up in the
scoring column."
If the defense continues to
stymie opponents and the scoring threats connect, one can only be led to believe that the

Hooters are playoff-bound.
The squad has an excellent
balance of youth and experience, and the upcoming
games should be a good
measuring stick of just how
strong the Jays really are.
Coach Tierney wants to take
one game at a time rather than
look ahead.
"We're in a good positon
now," Tierney remarked. "The
attitude and depth of talent on
this team are both excellent.
With successive wins, we gain
confidence and place ourselves
in a better positon to realize our
goals. Taking one game at a
time, we should be successful at
the season's end." Hopkins'
road swing rounds out with
meetings at Ursinus tomorrow
and Division II power
U.M.B.C. Wednesday. They
return home Friday to face
Dickinson.
